title: Before Unilever, Nelson Peltz Took Aim at P&G's 'Thicket'; P&G overhauled its management after investor's proxy fight but didn't follow his advice to de-emphasize big brands, which have fueled strong sales
text:
During Mr. Peltz's tenure on P&G's board, which ended in August 2021, the company overhauled its operations and in turn accelerated sales growth, positioning itself to capitalize on the pandemic and regularly outperform its rivals.

Now Mr. Peltz is joining the board of the biggest of those competitors, Unilever PLC, maker of Dove soap and Hellmann's mayonnaise.

Unilever has its own matrix-management woes. Mr. Peltz says the company has "significant potential."

His entry to P&G was less diplomatic. Mr. Peltz said P&G was mired in the past and that it had settled for mediocrity. He called the company a suffocating bureaucracy. On the sidelines of a shareholder meeting, Mr. Peltz accused then-Chief Executive Officer David Taylor of not listening to him.

He called for organizing P&G into three units and recruiting executives from outside the company. He also pushed P&G to downsize its ranks and revamp how executives were compensated.

Mr. Taylor and his lieutenants said at the time that the management overhaul Mr. Peltz called for was already under way.

Mr. Taylor said some of Mr. Peltz's ideas were wrongheaded, namely his view that the company should move away from big-name brands like Tide and Pampers in favor of niche names with youth appeal.

The two sides waged a monthslong, public battle before P&G agreed to add Mr. Peltz to the board following a shareholder vote that was so close the result was in dispute.

Some of Mr. Peltz's initial requests never materialized. P&G didn't reorganize into three units. While the company made a string of smaller acquisitions, P&G remains as focused as ever on its biggest brands, most of which saw surging demand amid the pandemic as consumers gravitated toward trusted names.

P&G did clear out "the thicket." Gone, too, is an executive-compensation structure that P&G leaders said failed to properly motivate leaders and hold them to account.

And while the company didn't organize itself into three operating units, it divided into seven operating units, each headed by a leader fully responsible for that unit's financials and profitability.

P&G CEO Jon Moeller, the former finance chief who succeeded Mr. Taylor in November, has said that Mr. Peltz lent urgency to P&G's restructuring. People familiar with the situation say Mr. Peltz also had a major role in revamping the company's compensation metrics so that leaders are more directly motivated to meet their goals.

The company unwound the management structure that had executives responsible for key brands and others responsible for geographic areas, a setup that resulted in dozens of managers reporting to multiple leaders. Also gone is the centralized product development that unilaterally controlled which ideas got approved and how they were marketed.

In April, the Cincinnati-based company posted its strongest quarterly sales gain in decades as customers continued to buy its pricier products despite rising inflation. Its share price is up 86% from when Mr. Peltz joined the board. The S&P 500 rose by about 50% in the same period.

Before leaving the board, Mr. Peltz backed Mr. Moeller, a rival during the proxy battle, to succeed Mr. Taylor.
